div.head: The Financial Stringency in Egypt
div.p: The scarcity of gold which again made itself felt last month was not nearly so acute as that experienced a few weeks previously, but, on the other hand, was much more unexpected. An insufficency of gold for currency requirements is no new phenomenon in this country and will, undoubtedly, continue to occur from time to time owing to the fact that any sudden and unexpected demand for gold can only be met by fresh inmports from Europe. The position in October was declared by people who know the country well as being the worst for many years, and the general opinion was that, after the heavy importations of gold, a similar situation could not possibly occur again this season. Events have proved the inaccuracy of these opinions, for during December there was a renewed gold famine, much less acute than its predessor it is true, but which at the same time made itself somewhat severely felt, as the exchange quotations show. On Saturday the 1st December banks' buying price of cheque on London was quoted at 97 to 97 whilst on the following Monday it went down to 97 and later in the week to 96 the average of the month being a shade under 97. Although other instances might be quoted, we will content to ourselves by mentioning merely the case of a certain native who, at the present moment, is reputed to have I.E. 20,000 (20,512) in National Bank of Egypt notes hidden in his house in one of the villages. The owner will not lend this money-more especially as it is against the Mohamedan religion to receive interest-neither will he employ it in any way until a favourable oppurtunity for the purchase of land occurs.

Cairo and Alexandria
Penny Postage
The postage on letters for British North Borneo has been reduced and fixed at 5 milliemes for every 15 grammes or fraction thereof.
A Love Tragedy
The Beni-Sogef Criminal Court has sentenced Awad Mohamed Mahdi to one year's imprisonment for the murder of Assaad Eft. Saleh who had had clandestine relations with Awad' fiancée.
The Plague
No fresh cases of plague are reported in to-day Yesterday's bulletin recorded the admission into hospital of the daughter of a Greek baker who has a shop in Haret Okelle Limoun. The case is bubonio.
Navigation on the Nile.

In connection with the Baneb Barrage works, a sadd is being constructed near the western bank, about one kilometre north of the town of Esneb. Boats of all kinds navigating the river should pass to the east of the red lights fixed on the western side.
Railway Robbery.

On Saturday evening, while train No. 670, on the Delta Light Railway, was between the stations of Borwah and Meballot Marhoom, a travelling cash case, containing upwards of £200, was stolen from the van. The omdebs of the two villages were advised and a search party of railway officials immediately set out from Tantah.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL OPERA HOUSE.
div.p: ( FROM OUR THEATRICAL CORRESPONDENT: )

"La Fille du Regiment” is as distinot a change as possible after two tew Mazgènets, Meyerbeer, and the other productions we have had so far. It is rather a delightful change, too; charming light must be known, and plenty of dialogue and acting. Mlle Charpentier and M. Darand (the sergeant) were quite good, always correct and with plenty of life as far as singing went; and they acted extremely well, better than they sang, I confess: Mlle Char, pentier looked enchantingly pretty, more so in her fashionable dress if possible that as the Vivandière ; and the sergeant was finely made up. M. Monteox had the part of Topio, and for once be sang in tone, but his voice is most distasteful, hopelessly affected, and entirely falsetto in the high notes.

The chorus were much as usual, but why do they look so deplorably stolid ! And do all French soldiers of the period wear those quaint American-striped trousers ? I rather wished they would black their faces and try a "coon" song. An elaborate ballet Wowed the opera, I confess I only ondored of it. I don't profess to understand ballet. It seemed except for Mlle Deliny, to consist in a species of swimming lessons--at least as far as the arms were concerned. Doubtless every gesture has its cabalistio meaning for the initiated. The music, by one Délibes, was rather pretty, with plenty of violine, floter, and French bora (which made one think of togs from Wagnerand that was nice).

With regard to fortbooming performances, "L'Afriesine" and "Messaline" are being "studied”. I asked about places. That is always a ground of complaint for those who do not buy seats for the season, and who really want to hear opera, and not their neighbours' opinions on Bourse questions. Seats on Monday, Tuesday, Thursday, and Saturday are practically unobtainable, but on Fridays there are plenty as the abonnement is only partial. When will the worthy managers understand that the whole reality of the opera and theatre is annihilated by that absurd "abonnement" system! It has no single saving merit: even the regularity of the receipts is fatal to the acting and singing, as no real effort or risk is involved : an empty house represents as much money-and far less noise-than a full house. That is perhaps a merit to a few keen listeners.

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE.
div.p: The opera season at the above theatre, thus far, has proved one of the best for several years. Each production has been well staged, and the artistes concerned are, for the most part, evenly balanced, --a very great assistance to the general success of any theatrical representation, whether dramatic or operatie. Saturday's performance of "Mefistofele" was certainly the most perfect of this opera. Signor Carlo Walter was in fine form, and his splendid voice was heard to great advantage. Sigoor Walter's histrioni ability is well known, but his Mephisto undoubtedly one of his best, and at the same time one of the most difficult roles. His impersonation is worthy of more than a passing comment, showing, as it does, most careful study, & commendable attention to the minutest detaile, a perfect picture of devilry and music, -a strange combination, perhaps, but one necessary in the present instances; in fine, an artistio performance worthy of Signor Walter.

Signor Agerbi as Paust appeared tired, and sang occasionally rather out of tune. His performance, however, was an excellent one Signora De Lerms was in perfect voice and sang admirably throughout the opera. We preferred her appearance in the second part as a brunette; why do the powers that be insist on a blonde Marguerite?

The other characters were well supported, and the orchestra worked splendidly. By the way, can nothing be done to prevent the discordant tootling and scraping indalgel in by the orchestra before each act ? Such noises cannot be intended for tuning, and they most jar on the sensitive ears of many patrons of the theatre.

div.head: M.P's. PEREGRINATIONS.
div.p: MR. ROBERTSON VISITS DENISHWAI.

Mr. J. M. Robertson, M.P., has been touring in the Gharbieh province. On Saturday night the M.P. was entertained by the Omdeb of Borwah. Our Shebin el Kom Correspondent, telegraphing this morning, says :- Rumours are current here that Mr. Robertson, M.P., paid a visit to the village of Denishwai yesterday. He has also visited this town.

The journeys of Mr. Robertson are being followed with great interest by the Nationalist Press, and with such detail that one might imagine that this gentleman was being escorted throughout Egypt by a phalanx of Nationalist journalists.

"Al Ahram" remarks: We are glad to see that Mr. Robertson is engaged in inspecting many native localities and departments and taking down in his note-book all that he can gather of the circumstances of the natives. This may be useful to this country later on. We have been informed that this member of Parliament refused to see some AngloEgyptian Government officials and refrained from seeing some other persons, whose object was only to serve the interests of the Occupation.

"Al Watan," the Coptic organ, remarks :The Islamic newepaper world has welcomed Mr. J. MR bertson, M.P., with such enthusiasm that some of our contemporaries seemed on the point of hailing him as the deliverer of Egypt and the defender of Islam. Yet this gentleman's views are utterly divergent from the native way of thinking. Mr. Robertson's friends in Egypt are persons in favour of religious instructior, while he is well known to be antagonistic to all creeds. He was a friend of Bradlaugh, the notorious Atheist, and he assisted him in editing a journal whose object was the promotion of Free Thought. He is one of the members of the committee of the Rationalist Press Association together with Hoxley, Tyndall, and Haeckel, who are among those European savants who deny revealed religion. He is the author of many works dealing with liberty of thought, i.e., the denial of taith and the fictions of religious peoples' belief. Yet the leaders of Islam in Egypt have nevertheless chosen Mr. Robertson, of all people in the world, as their sincere friend, for they consider him as the man with the truest ideas! Is not this a carious anomaly?
"Al Lewa," of yesterday's date, gives the following account of Mr. Robertson's progress in the provinces :-

News comes from the Bebera that Mr. J. "M. Robertson one of the commissions composed of Liberal members of the British Parliament who are studying the condition of Egypt, arrived at Itay-el-Baroud on Friday, where he was welcomed by a number of omdehs and notables of the Mondirieh who happened to be gathered at the station. The Markaz Mamoar introduced the best known among them to Mr. Robertson, who shook hands with the natives and expressed pleasure at meeting them. His object in coming, he said was to travel through the provinces and study the manner of living of the fellaheen. Mr. Robertson, who was accompanied by Abd ElHamid Ammar, proceeded to Nahiel Biban, where he was received as a guest by the Ammar family. The natives evince their I pleasure at seeing Mr. Robertson, knowing the object he has in view.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ARMY.
div.p: A special Cairo District Order states that "His Highness the Khedive bas been mort graciously pleased to express to His Excellency the Sirdar his entire satisfaction with the smart appearance of the troops and the manner in which the various movements were carried out on the occasion of the review held in honour of the anniversary of his accession."

div.head: MUSTAPHA KAMEL.
div.p: STILL ANOTHER INTERVIEW.
A Havas telegram from Paris states that Mastapha Kamel, in an interview with a representative of the "Temps," said that Egypt was ripe for liberty and not resigned to suffering.

"Al Lewa's" Paris correspondent telegraphs that the "Temps" published on Saturday Mustapha Pasba Kamel's declarations in regard to British policy and aims in Egypt. Kamel Pasba pointed out that no agreement was possible between the Egyptians and the English so long as the latter adopted the same policy.

div.head: TURKEY AND EGYPT.
div.p: The statement contained in Constantinople telegrams to the Vienna Press that the station in Egypt is causing preoccupation on the part of Yildiz Kiosk and the Porte is unfounded. Such reports are spread by interested parties who desire to disturb the relations of Great Britain and Turkey. Equally mischievous is the further statement regarding British attacks on the position of Mukhtar Pasha, the Porte's High Commissioner, whose status, as is already known, the British and Egyptian Governments decline to recognise officially.

div.head: BANK OF ABYSSINIA.
div.p: A persistent report is current in Cairo that Mr. MacGillivray, Governor of the Bank of Abyssinia, will not return to Addis Abeba, but will shortly open an important exchange business in the capital. We have reason to believe that there is some truth in this report.

div.head: THỂ NEW CAIRO BOURSE.
div.p: A report is current to the effect that H. H. the Khedive has offered to lease at a reasonable figure 1,000 metres of the land be has recently purobased from the German community, opposite the Hotel d'Angleterre, Cairo, for the purpose of the new Boarse, the cost of building which he is so willing to defray and to charge a rent for the same.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ESTATES.
div.p: The Egyptian Estates, Limited, has under its agreement given formal notice to Mr. Salamone Conegliano, the tenant of the Alhambhra Theatre at Alexandria, to quit in six months' time. This step has been decided on owing to important developments in property in that district of the city.

div.head: L'EPARGNE IMMOBILIERE LIMITED
div.p: The statutory meeting of the above company was held on Saturday at their offices, 24, Sbaris el Maghraby, Cairo, the president, Mr. Joseph Vaast, presiding.

After the report had been read and approved, it was unanimously decided to increase the capital of the company to £800,000 by the issue of 175,000 new shares of £4 each, and full power was given to the directors to dispose of this additional capital to the best interests of the company.

Mr. Boutigny gave a short resumé of the doings and intentions of the company, and among other things, mentioned that the company bad bought 80,000 metres of land on Ghezireb Island on very exceptional conditions, and this land will be resold with facilities of payment, extending over 30 years. There are 61 lots, and already 10 have been sold : it is expected that the remainder will be disposed of in two months. This arrangement will prove most advantageous for the buyers as well as for the company, who will make a profit of about £160,000. The company have also concluded other transactions from which large profits will be derived.
The company are buying land and paying for same in shares of the new issue, and a large portion of this new issue has already been placed in this manner.
The shareholders will certainly have every reason to congratulate themselves at the end of the financial year.

div.head: 50 MILLIONAIRES FOR EGYPT.
div.p: RECORD PASSENGER LISTS

The Cunard liner Caronia and the White Star liner Cardio. which left New York on the 5th inst. for Alexandria, are bringing no less than fifty millionaires to Egypt. They have only first class passengers on board from nearly all the principal cities in the United States. None of the passengers are paying less than £280 each for the trip

The Cedrio and Caronis have the largest number of persons on board bound for Egypt that over lett New York at one time. In the office 28 of all the big steamship companies in New York it was asserted that an anosgally largo exodus to Egypt and Southern Italy is expected this winter. In the last few years, Egypt has been making great inroads on the mid winter Italian tourist traffic.

Among the prominent New Yorkers on board the Cedrio are: Mr. and Mrs. W. P. Stafford, Mr, and Mrs. J. William Beekman, Dr. and Mrs. R. . Derby, Mr. and Mrs. E. W. Potter, Professor Henry Fairfield Osborn, Mr. H. W. Cannon, Mr. and Mrs. W. D. Guthrie, Mr. and Mrs. T. P. Pisko, Me. C. W. Leavitt, Jr., Mr. C. D. Paller, Captain H. J. Hoehler, U.S. A., and Mr. Hoebler, Mr. and Mrs. George Gifford, Mr. Frederick Gebhardt, Mrs. Frederick Neilson, Mt. P. N. Doubleday and Mr. Henry Clark.

On the Caronia are: Mr. Elwin C. Atkinson, Mr. and Mrs. James H. Aldrich, Dr. Edward P: Brewer, Mr. George K. Baker, Mirg Helen Collamore, Mr. Aaron M. Crane, Mr. W. F. Doty, Amerióan Consul at Tabriz, Persia ; Mr. Henry T. Parrar, Mr. and Mrs. Hagh A. Marray, Mr. and Mrs. W. H. Moffitt, Dr. and Mrs. M. Loeb, Mrs. Pierre Lorillard, Mr. and Mrs. Horace L. Hotohkiss, Mr. Albert G. C. Hsbn, Mr. George A. Ganther, Mr. and Mrs. Alfred T. White, Mr. Charles H. Werner, Mr, and Mrs. Robert A. Van Wyck and Mrs. James B. Hendrick
The Caronia left Gibraltar yesterday on her way to Naples and Alexandria. Sbe is due here on the 19th inst. and returns to New York on the 20th inst, via Rome and Naples.

div.head: NOTES FROM SUEZ.
div.p: STEAMER AGROUND IN CANAL.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)

Suez, Sunday The French steamer America, bound to Jeddab with Algerian pilgrims, is aground in the Suez Canal, near the small lake, since early this morning, and is stopping the traffic. The tog Titan has been despatched to her assistance.
The 8.8. Tangistan, which was ashore at Saakin, arrived at Saez this morning, and will go into drydock for repairs
NOTES FROM PORT SAID.
(FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT.)

Port Said Friday. The Italian praiser Marcatonis Cologne has has arrived here and will await the arrival of H.R. H. the Duke of Udins, who is returning from a tour round the world, and is expected early next week. : Last Tuesday, Mr. Black, a young Boglishman who is making stay at Port Said, commenced a 10 days' walk to Cairo and back. Yes. terday, at noon, he was reported to have passed Ismailia, Mr. Black is a good all round sportsman'; he has played for Port Said, and op more than one occasion he has got them out of a difficult at bookey, cricket, and football.

Port Said, Sonday, The commander of the Italian cruiser yesterday paid a visit to the Governor, accompanied by the Italian Consol. In the afternoon the Governor returned the visit. The cruiser left this morning for Suez.

div.head: IMPORTANT FIND AT LUXOR
div.p: Mr. Theodore M. Davis has discovered in the Valley of the Kings the tomb of the great Queen Thi, wife of Amenhotep III. It contains ber mommy, coffin, canopie jars, and numerous other beautiful and interesting objects. The inspirations will be welcomed by all Egyptologists.

div.head: THE KHEDIYE.
div.p: H. H. the Khedive, who came down to Alexandria on Friday night, will spend a few days inspecting his estates at Mariout.
After Kourban Beyram the Khedive intends to go on a trip to the desert.

div.head: EDINBURGH.
div.p: Post-Graduate Vacation Course in
Medicine. In connection with the UNIVERSITY
and ROYAL COLLEGES.
Courses will be held from the 2nd to the 28th September, 1907. For Syllabus and further particulars apply,
Secretary, University New Buildings,
EDINBURG, 2911--2-w-1
Scotland.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: K. S. C.
JUNIOR CHAMPIONSHIP POLO
"JOURNAMENT. The cold windy weather, and the absence of a band no doubt accounted for the small gathering assembled to witness these matches on Saturday.
First MATCH E INNISKILLING DRAGOONS 6. K.8.C. Mr. Merriman I. Mr. Spier 1 Mr. Nixon II Capt. Kennedy II. Mr. Holland III. Capt. Hadow III. Mr. Bowen, back. ' Capt. Bartlett back.

The match began tamely, play being slow and rather interesting. In the second chokker was brighter, both sides, however, missing easy shots at goal. In the third chokker Capt. Bartlett, who bad been playing a good game throughout, made a fine ron ap the ground, and Mr. Spier, bo!ding the opposing back, soored a good goal. Soore : K.8.C. I goal to love. Mr. Bowen shortly afterwards equalized. Play now became faster, Capt. Bartlett especially being conspicuous. Capt. Hadow also seemed to find his game at last, and scored a clever goal, bringing the score to 2 to 1 in favour of the K.S.C., and in the last minute Capt. Bartlett added a third.
Final score: K.S.C., 3 goals. Inniskilling Dragoons, 1 goal.
'SECOND MATCH. TIGERS v. COLDSTREAM GUARDS No. I. TEAM. Capt. Sterling I. Mr. Warde Aldom Mr. MacGillivray II. Mr. Beckwith Mr. Jepkinson III. Mr. Gibbs Mr. Reid, back. Mr. Bentinck

These two sides had met twice before in practice games, each side winning a match. This naturally added extra interest to the game. From the throw-in Mr. Jenkinson came away, bat missed his shot, and some give-and take in the middle of the ground followed. In the second chokker the play was keener and faster than ever, Mr. Jenkinson doing great work for his side, bat be missed an easy goal. We noticed a good deal of missing on both sides, but the keenness of all the players made up for this. It was not until the fourth and last chukker that Mr. Beckwith scored a goal for the Guards. This pat K. 8. C. on their metal, Captain Sterling equalizing. Shortly afterwards Mr. Jenkinson added yet another, which brought the score to 2 to 1 in favour of the K. 8. C. Bat the Guards were not done with, and made a most determined attack on the goal of the K. 8. C., who, after saving their goal several times, were at last besten in their detence. This brought the soore to 2 all. Ten seconds later the bell rang, 80 an extra ohakker bad to be played. The Guards, who evidently were still fall of fight, soon settled matters, a good run up the ground resulting in a goal. Final scores : Tigers, 2 goals ; Coldstream Guards, 3 goals.
So ended a very keen, hard contested match. The next tie will be played off on Tuesday.

div.head: FAYOUM RACES.
div.p: The first winter meeting of the Fayoum Racing Club will be held at Payoum on Friday next. There are five events on the card, aod entries must be made before Thareday to the hops. secretaries, Mr. R. H. Way or Abmed Efendi Fatbi, Fayoum. The Adviser to the Ministry of the Interior and Lady Victoria Macbell are to be present. Any tourists wishing to attend this op-country meeting should notify one of the hon. secretarie', who will arrange for lanoh and arabias to the course at P.T. 30 a bead.
ALEXANDRIA MIXED COURT.

Mallison, (29). G. Rolo, |(89), I. Bindernagel, (28) L'Escoffier. (28). Henri Nabman, (28), Dante Rieti, (28), Emmanuel Stro-8, (78), Sidney Carver, (97),
A. Pirenay, (27), P. Hess, (27), 0. Rothacker, |(27), Luigi Stagni, (27). Adolphe Struas, (27), H. Sobæller, (26), 8. Well Off, (26).

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Papayanni leader Alexandria left for Malta on Saturday and is expected to arrive here to-morrow afternoon with a sengers and mails.
. The Messageries Maritimes 8.8. Equateur, from Marseille, passed the Straits of Messina I on Saturday, and is dae here tomorrow.
The Cunard S.8. Veria arrived at Liverpool on Saturday morning.

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL
div.p: Facing the Sea on the New Quay of Alexandr
FIRST-CLASS HOTEL Lately Built' and Furnished.
TERMS P.T. 50 PER DAY. Special terms to Government Officials.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince Aziz Pasha Hassan came down to Alexandria yesterday from Cairo.

The Khedive has conferred the grade of Mirmiran on Monbeb Bey, Governor of the Haez Canal, and Dr. Mohamed Bey Shukri, both of whom now become Pasb and the Medjidie of the Yad class on De. Almy Pasba.
We regret to announce the death, which took place on Friday night in Cairo, of Youssef Bey Sbawki, Counsellor to the Native Court of Appeal.
The French Government has conferred the Legion of Honour on Count Alexander de Zogheb, the Portuguese Consul in Alexandria.
M. Empain, the Belgian capitalist, who is o largely interested in Egypt, has been made Baron by the King of the Belgians.
Boghor Pasha Nabar is arriving from Eprope on the 15tb inst.
M. Nico'aos Thectokis, son of the Hellenio Premier, left on Saturday for Cairo, and will have an audience of the Khedive.
Lient. Lord A. J. Percy, 3rd Battalion Grenadier Gaarde, has been selected for employment with the Egyptian Army.
Sir Nowell and Lady Salmon will spend the next few weeks in Cairo, where Sir William and Lady East have recently arrived.
We regret that Dean Butcher's condition is still such as to cause considerable anxiety to his many friends.
Col. Hopkinson Bey, Commandant of the Alexandria City Police, left yesterday for Cairo.

The following were that passengers by the train deluxe for Upper Egypt on Friday night : Saad Pasha Zaghloul, Minister of Education ; Ahmed Effendi Nagaib, Mr. Haar, Mr. 8 Halperin, Mrs. Hayes Saleen, Miss O'Meara, Miss J. O'Mears, M. and Mme Schwein.
Mr. Schafer, of the Shannon, Limited, has arrived in Cairo and is stopping at Shepheard's Hotel.
| Mr. and Mrs. Bland-Satton arrived in London last week from Syria.

Among the latest arrivals at the Savoy Hotel, Port Said, we notice : Major General Ballock, CB, Capt. Danbar, Lieut.-Col. Allfort, Mr. MacMillan and party. Major Fryer, Major and Mrs. Churcb ward, Comtesse Tysokievicz, Graf Børnsdorff, Major and Mrs. Hall, Baroneas Cambo, Miss B. Serhardt, Mr. S.
